title: How to Make a Rubber Stamp for Letterboxing

steps.headline: Purchase the materials at local craft chains.
steps.description: The rubber pad and the lino cutter tools may be found near the rubber stamping supplies but often they are found in the calligraphy or carving supplies. If you do not find them at your local craft store you may check in college book stores or there are sources online. You can also carve erasers. They are cheaper, but smaller.

steps.headline: Choose an image about the size of a business card or wallet size photo.
steps.description: For inspiration, use Google image search and choose black and white images. If you draw your own, draw a simple line drawing (think of what you see in children's coloring books).

steps.headline: Cover the back of your image with pencil.
Trace it onto the rubber pad.
Use the pen to write directly onto the rubber.
Carefully carve your stamp using the tools.
steps.description: Start with small tools, and start in the tight areas. Remove the pink and leave the ink. Do not go too deep. Go straight down into the rubber, not at an angle. Make strokes that start near ink and move away from it. Let up pressure just before arriving at another ink mark. Remove tool and start from opposite side. When making curves, turn the pad, not the tool.

steps.headline: Leave the area around the image for last:Remove the stamp with the knife-like tool.
Ink your stamp and practice.
steps.description: Use your tools to carefully remove any unwanted or stray marks.

steps.headline: Mount your stamps on children's blocks with Gorilla glue or Craft Goop.

text:
Purchase the materials at local craft chains. The rubber pad and the lino cutter tools may be found near the rubber stamping supplies but often they are found in the calligraphy or carving supplies. If you do not find them at your local craft store you may check in college book stores or there are sources online. You can also carve erasers. They are cheaper, but smaller. Choose an image about the size of a business card or wallet size photo. For inspiration, use Google image search and choose black and white images. If you draw your own, draw a simple line drawing (think of what you see in children's coloring books). Cover the back of your image with pencil. Trace it onto the rubber pad. Pen works well. Use the pen to write directly onto the rubber. Carefully carve your stamp using the tools. Start with small tools, and start in the tight areas. Remove the pink and leave the ink. Do not go too deep. Go straight down into the rubber, not at an angle. Make strokes that start near ink and move away from it. Let up pressure just before arriving at another ink mark. Remove tool and start from opposite side. When making curves, turn the pad, not the tool. Leave the area around the image for last:Remove the stamp with the knife-like tool. "} Ink your stamp and practice. Use your tools to carefully remove any unwanted or stray marks. Mount your stamps on children's blocks with Gorilla glue or Craft Goop.
